anatomy.course: Mesenteric border of colon, 1-2 cm from wall
anatomy.connections: Links ileocolic, right colic, middle colic, left colic, sigmoid, superior rectal
anatomy.vasa_recta: Short and long branches supply bowel wall

griffiths_point.significance: Vulnerable in SMA or IMA occlusion

sudeck_point.significance: Critical for sigmoid viability after IMA ligation

aortic_surgery.IMA_ligation: Safe if marginal artery intact and backbleeding adequate
aortic_surgery.risk_factors: Hypotension, prior radiation, atherosclerosis of arc
aortic_surgery.monitoring: Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy if concern for ischemia

clinical_significance.colon_surgery: Preserve marginal artery when possible during resection

imaging.CTA: Coronal reconstructions show marginal artery course

definition.@value: Continuous arterial arcade along the mesenteric border of the colon connecting SMA and IMA branches, with vulnerable watershed zones at Griffiths point (splenic flexure) and Sudeck point (rectosigmoid).

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Trace the marginal artery of Drummond along the colon
Identify the two critical watershed zones
Understand why splenic flexure and rectosigmoid are vulnerable to ischemia
clinical_pearls: Griffiths point (splenic flexure) - marginal artery absent in up to 50%
Sudeck point (rectosigmoid) - last sigmoid branch critical for sigmoid viability
Ischemic colitis preferentially affects watershed zones - look there first
After AAA repair with IMA ligation, SIGMOID is most commonly ischemic
Check backbleeding from IMA stump during AAA repair - guides reimplantation decision
